 You can shine your shoes and wear a suit
 You can comb your hair and look quite cute
 You can hide your face behind a smile
 One thing you can't hide
 Is when you're crippled inside 
 
 You can wear a mask and paint your face
 You can call yourself the human race
 You can wear a collar and a tie
 One thing you can't hide
 Is when you're crippled inside 
 
 Well now you know that your
 Cat has nine lives
 Nine lives to itself
 But you only got one
 And a dog's life ain't fun
 Mamma take a look outside 
 
 You can go to church and sing a hymn
 You can judge me by the color of my skin
 You can live a lie until you die
 One thing you can't hide
 Is when you're crippled inside...
 
 Long Live John Lennon @--}'----

 I too, like Lennon, at least musically. My favourite Beatles track is "A Day in the Life" which was principally a Lennon song.
 
 However, it was Paul who moved them ahead, artistically. Lennon, you might recall was happily married and living a suburban existence with wife #1, whilst single Paul was with the arts scence with Jane Asher and family.
 
 Lennon never was sure where he stood, sometimes he was counter-culture, sometimes anti-left ('you can count me out' he said in Revolution).
 
 Musically, George was a mere shadow. His solo compositions, both post-Beatles and during, are easy to forget.
 
 A very good book to read is "Revolution in the Head" by Ian McDonald which goes through every one of the Beatles releases and tells you how they are structured, where mistakes were made etc.

LedZeppelin

The Beatles were definitely the greatest and most influential band in all of history. John Lennon, Paul McCartney, George Harrison, and Ringo Starr all were critical ingredients in the best band of all time and all of their contributions to music should be recognized. I'm sure Paul doesn't want people rambling on about how he was the main man in the Beatles and I'm sure John Lennon wouldn't like people gloating about him being the best in the Beatles either. Let's just recognize their musical abilities and what they gave to music instead of talking about which was better then the other.

 I actually don't like Paul McCartney, as a person.
 
 He was set to tour here in Australia a while ago. He was only going to do one lousy show in Melbourne, anyway, but then he cancelled. He claimed because it was so close to the Bali Bombing that it would be in bad taste. Instead, he went on to tour a few more shows in the USA.
 
 He used the Bali tragedy as a means of worming out. Other bands still came, and regularly do; U2, Rolling Stones, the Chilli Peppers etc. I was disgusted that he'd use this tragedy as an excuse - considering he did a concert in New York shortly after 9/11... concerts aren't the issue.
 
 He was due to come here in his 1989-90 tour, but cancelled to do a few more shows in the USA, so he's not changed.
 
 All up, he came here with the Beatles, once.
 With Wings, once.
 Then in 1992.
 
 We seem to be a part of the world he's not keen to re-visit.
